stream_context.summary: Nearly the whole session is devoted to importing and integrating a large batch of new models from Biobak (switches, enemies, props). Kaze also prototypes Bowser’s office, chases several Fast64 / combiner bugs, and keeps an eye on performance on real N64 hardware.
level: various existing levels for asset tests

development_findings.summary: Bowser’s office room has been roughed-in; Kaze settled on overall room size and a front-desk NPC concept ('guy in the wall').
development_findings.quote: Alright, this is going to be Bowser's office. I think that's a good size for it.

development_findings.summary: Render-time optimisation continues: course 1 currently takes ~26 ms per frame; Kaze hopes to shave it to ~24.5 ms by micro-optimising the sign renderer and other hotspots.
development_findings.quote: In course one, it takes 26 milliseconds to render the whole frame. I think we can get it down to maybe 24.5.

development_findings.summary: Recording real-hardware footage exposed floating-point exceptions in several levels (e.g., Goomba crush scaling to zero). Fixes are ‘annoying but not difficult’.
development_findings.quote: A lot of the levels have floating point exceptions when you enter them right now on N64... Probably because the scale goes to exactly zero.

development_findings.summary: Steel-beam textures upgraded from CI4 (1-bit alpha) to RGBA16 + separate alpha mask, giving smoother edges and less ‘crust’.
development_findings.quote: Because we now have 8-bit alpha... we now have much, much smoother edges here.

development_findings.summary: Blue-coin switch completely redesigned: new model, no separate down-animation (instant 5-frame change), scaled 1.5× larger; manual render-area boxing used until Fast64 auto-bounds exists.
development_findings.quote: A five-frame thing doesn’t need an animation... I think this looks really good.

development_findings.summary: Cap switches overhauled: top and base fused into single model; three intermediate models used instead of bones; vertex-colour + world-light solution chosen so they sit naturally in each level; colours assigned (red, cyan for ice, dark blue for bomb/cloud).
development_findings.quote: We can have our cake and eat it too... it looks like it's actually in the level.

development_findings.summary: Old ‘cap-switch test level’ code discovered and removed as unnecessary legacy.
development_findings.quote: There’s no reason for the check to exist, so I'm removing it.

development_findings.summary: Fast64 limitations identified: shared textures can cause premature eviction; armature re-imports break pivot points (e.g., fish fin), and some GL-layout presets misrender.
development_findings.quote: If you re-import the armature, Fast64 will fuck it up.

development_findings.summary: Combiner troubleshooting: ground-pound stars and blue flames rendered incorrectly until Kaze rebuilt the combiner manually, discovering a checkbox/clamp error.
development_findings.quote: There must be a combiner setting somewhere that fucked it up and I don't know what the setting was—now it works.

development_findings.summary: Realised Nemu64 reproduces the same crash locations as real hardware, so it can be used for faster crash debugging.
development_findings.quote: NEMU crashes here just like N64 would... that is going to save me so much time.

development_findings.summary: Decision: standard green pipes will eventually be baked directly into level geometry to save draw calls.
development_findings.quote: I also think we're gonna put all the normal pipes hard-coded into the level in the end... just for a tiny bit of performance.

context_findings.summary: Kaze regularly studies MrBeast videos to understand audience appeal for his own content.
context_findings.quote: I actually study MrBeast's videos like a fucking nerd. I look at them and be like, ‘Oh, why do people like this?’

context_findings.summary: He values micro-optimisation to near-meme levels (e.g., saving 50 ns) but frames it as part of the project’s identity.
context_findings.quote: At this point, I'm just doing it for the meme.

context_findings.summary: Workout schedule shifted, causing chat to ‘gaslight’ him on what day it is; hints at juggling personal routine with dev streams.
context_findings.quote: I changed my workout routine this week... so the gaslight almost worked.

context_findings.summary: Strong opinion on software design: opposes private variables; prefers transparency and hardware-level thinking.
context_findings.quote: Private variables are completely useless and should never exist... They mean nothing to the processor.

biobak.summary: Delivered a large asset drop: blue-coin switch, cap switches, fish remodel, Goomba remodel, new ground-pound stars, flame textures, quarter 8-bit pipe piece, and ‘sludge blarg’ boss block with scrolling eyes/teeth.
biobak.quote: So we are going to import all of Biobak's remade models today.

biobak.summary: Actively iterated textures and colours live on stream (e.g., switch contrast, coin icon, star glow) based on Kaze & Lilaa feedback.

zeina.summary: Working on Wiggler walk/run animation; reported progress in chat and planned to show a preview.
zeina.quote: I think I finally got Wiggler's walk or run looking right.

key_stories.title: Reinventing the Cap Switch
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Biobak retire the iconic Mario 64 cap switch in favour of a cleaner, lighting-aware model that still evokes the original.
key_stories.challenge: Vanilla cap switch had separate top/base parts, ugly textures, and ignored world lighting.
key_stories.process: Fused geometry, experimented with bones vs. multiple models, tweaked vertex colours and combiner maths, and matched colours to new cap types.
key_stories.outcome: New switches look consistent across levels and animate instantly without extra code overhead.
key_stories.key_quote: We can have our cake and eat it too—it looks like it's actually in the level.

key_stories.title: The Combiner Mystery
key_stories.summary: A subtle graphics-pipeline flag caused star and flame textures to degrade; Kaze hunted it down live.
key_stories.challenge: Ground-pound stars and blue flames appeared grainy or white-boxed in both emulator and hardware.
key_stories.process: Tested clamp/mirror flags, rebuilt the combiner from scratch, compared NEMU vs. Fast64 output.
key_stories.outcome: Single mis-set clamp option located; assets now render correctly; new debugging workflow validated.
key_stories.key_quote: There must be a combiner setting somewhere that fucked it up—and now it works.

key_stories.title: Steel Beams Get a 2024 Makeover
key_stories.summary: An everyday support texture became a mini tech breakthrough.
key_stories.challenge: Old CI4 steel texture produced jagged alpha edges on real N64.
key_stories.process: Swapped to RGBA16 plus higher-res alpha mask; demonstrated before-after in stream.
key_stories.outcome: Crisper yet softer beams; shows team’s willingness to spend effort on micro visual upgrades.
key_stories.key_quote: It is blurrier and crispier—because the detail texture has half the detail now but the edges are much crisper.

open_questions.context: Only basic room dimensions and a receptionist NPC concept were mentioned.
questions: What narrative or gameplay purpose will Bowser's office serve?
How will the office visually reflect Bowser’s personality in this hack?
Are any special mechanics or cutscenes planned for this area?

open_questions.context: Crushing Goombas and entering certain levels crash the N64 build; fixes are ‘annoying’ but unspecified.
questions: What is the root cause of the current FP exceptions?
How widespread are they across enemy types and levels?
What is the planned timetable for a stable hardware build?

open_questions.context: Kaze noted ‘something really weird’ with wall collisions underwater; immediate death on level entry in one test.
questions: When did this regression appear and what commit introduced it?
Is the issue tied to recent Fast64 changes or custom collision code?
What debugging steps remain before a fix?

open_questions.context: Shared texture optimisation broke colour swaps and caused compiler errors.
questions: How will the team reconcile Fast64’s limitations with the desire for shared textures?
Will the Goomba need a unique workflow compared to other enemies?
Could a custom exporter or script bypass Fast64’s eviction logic?

open_questions.context: New model delivered with scrolling textures but no behaviour yet.
questions: What role will the sludge blarg play in gameplay terms (boss, hazard, puzzle)?
What technical approach will be used for its multi-texture scrolling and damage states?
Who will handle animation and AI coding for this enemy?
